title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ATLANTA (AP) — On a night destined to be remembered for one man’s singular brilliance, the Atlanta Hawks were not merely a basketball team; they were witnesses to history, riding the supernova performance of Dikembe Mutombo to a commanding 98-80 victory over the Charlotte Hornets.

While Glen Rice fought valiantly for Charlotte, pouring in a game-high 29 points, his effort was rendered a footnote. This was Mutombo’s night, his domain, his masterpiece. The final stat line was staggering: 31 points, a monstrous 26 rebounds, and 6 blocked shots. He didn't just dominate the paint; he annexed it, turning the key into a no-fly zone where Hornets’ hopes came to die.

The game was a defensive clinic orchestrated by its centerpiece. Every Mutombo rebound was a possession denied, every blocked shot a statement of territorial dominance. His 26 boards were an act of sheer will, vacuuming every missed shot and extinguishing any chance of a Charlotte second-chance opportunity. Offensively, he was just as potent, his 31 points a relentless hammering on the interior that the Hornets had no answer for.

The Hawks, feeding off his energy, played with a suffocating confidence. Mookie Blaylock orchestrated the offense with 13 points and 9 assists, while Steve Smith added a steady 16. But they were supporting actors in the Mutombo epic.

In the end, the 98-80 final score was almost incidental. The real story was etched in the history books: a legendary, Herculean effort from one of the game’s greatest defenders, a performance for the ages that lifted his team to a decisive victory. On this night, the Atlanta Hawks didn’t just win a game; they hosted a legend.
